revision.text:
{{Infobox games | Name = 1983 South Pacific Games | Logo = 1983_South_Pacific_Games_logo.png | Size = 150px | Optional caption = | Host city = [[Apia]] | Country = [[Western Samoa]] | Motto = | Nations participating = 15 | Athletes participating = 2,500+ {{ref|athletes|a}} | Events = 13 sports | Opening ceremony = {{Start date|1983|9|5}} | Closing ceremony = {{End date|1983|9|16}} | Officially opened by = {{nowrap|[[Malietoa Tanumafili II]]}} | Athlete's Oath = | Judge's Oath = | Torch Lighter = | Stadium = | previous = [[1979 South Pacific Games|1979 Suva]] | next = [[1987 South Pacific Games|1987 Nouméa]] }} The '''1983 South Pacific Games''', held at [[Apia]] in [[Western Samoa]] from 5–16 September 1983, was the seventh edition of the [[South Pacific Games]]. ==Participating countries== Fifteen nations competed at the 1983 South Pacific Games: {{columns-list|colwidth=17em| *{{flag|American Samoa}} *{{flag|Cook Islands}} *{{flag|Fiji}} *{{flag|French Polynesia|1946}} *{{flag|Guam}} *{{flag|New Caledonia|1853}} *{{flag|Niue}} {{ref|niue|b}} *{{flag|Norfolk Island}} *{{flag|Papua New Guinea}} *{{flag|Solomon Islands}} *{{flag|Tokelau}} {{ref|tokelau|c}} *{{flag|Tonga}} *{{flag|Vanuatu}} *{{flag|Wallis and Futuna}} *{{flag|Western Samoa}} }} ==Sports== Despite swimming being a compulsory sport for the South Pacific Games, there was no facility built in Apia to host swimming events in 1983. There were thirteen sports contested at the 1983 South Pacific Games: {{col-float|firstcol=17em}} * {{GamesSport|Athletics |Events= 38 }}{{ref|stamps|d}} *{{GamesSport|Basketball |Events= 2 |Format=m}}{{ref|basketball|e}} * {{GamesSport|Bowls |Events= 8 |Format=m}}{{ref|bowls|f}} * {{GamesSport|Boxing |Events=12 |Format=m}}{{ref|stamps|d}} * {{GamesSport|Football |Events= 1 }}{{ref|stamps|d}} * {{GamesSport|Golf |Events= 4 |Format=m}}{{ref|stamps|d}} * {{GamesSport|Netball |Events= 1}}{{ref|netball|g}} {{col-float-break|nextcol=17em}} * {{GamesSport|Rugby union |Events= 1 }}{{ref|stamps|c}} * {{GamesSport|Squash |Events= 4 |Format=m}}{{ref|squash|f}} * {{GamesSport|Table tennis |Events= 7 |Format=m}} * {{GamesSport|Tennis |Events= 7 |Format=m}}{{ref|stamps|d}} * {{GamesSport|Volleyball |Events= 2 |Format=m}}{{ref|volleyball|i}} * {{GamesSport|Weightlifting |Events=10 |Format=m}}{{ref|stamps|d}} {{col-float-end}}

Note: A number in parentheses indicates how many medal events were contested in that sport (where known).
==Final medal table== New Caledonia topped the table ahead of hosts Western Samoa: {{Medals table | caption = | host = | flag_template = | event = | team = | gold_NCL = 24| silver_NCL = 20| bronze_NCL = 19| name_NCL = {{flagteam|NCL|1853}} | gold_WSM = 20| silver_WSM = 13| bronze_WSM = 12| name_WSM = {{flag|Western Samoa}} (WSM) | gold_PYF = 13| silver_PYF = 17| bronze_PYF = 14| name_PYF = {{flagteam|PYF|1946}} | gold_PNG = 12| silver_PNG = 17| bronze_PNG = 14 | gold_FIJ = 12| silver_FIJ = 17| bronze_FIJ = 14 | gold_ASA = 4 | silver_ASA = 4 | bronze_ASA = 6 | gold_COK = 3 | silver_COK = 4 | bronze_COK = 0 | gold_GUM = 3 | silver_GUM = 2 | bronze_GUM = 1 | gold_NFI = 2 | silver_NFI = 0 | bronze_NFI = 1 | gold_WLF = 1 | silver_WLF = 2 | bronze_WLF = 5 | gold_SOL = 1 | silver_SOL = 1 | bronze_SOL = 2 | gold_VAN = 1 | silver_VAN = 0 | bronze_VAN = 9 | gold_TON = 1 | silver_TON = 0 | bronze_TON = 5 | gold_NIU = 0 | silver_NIU = 0 | bronze_NIU = 0 | gold_TKL = 0 | silver_TKL = 0 | bronze_TKL = 0 }} ==See also== *[[Athletics at the 1983 South Pacific Games]] *[[Football at the 1983 South Pacific Games]] ==Notes==
{{note|athletes|a}} Attempts to reduce the size the games were not successful and more than 2,500 athletes took part in 1983. {{note|niue|b}} Niue competed in the soccer and rugby competitions. {{note|niue|c}} Tokelau competed in the rugby competition. {{note|stamps|d}} Postage stamps depicting athletics, netball, tennis, weightlifting, boxing, soccer, golf and rugby were issued by Samoa for the 1983 South Pacific Games. {{note|basketball|e}} Fiji's women's basketball team won gold in 1983. {{note|bowls|f}} Bowls: Fiji won gold in the women's pairs at Apia in 1983. {{note|netball|g}} Cook Islands won the netball gold in 1983. {{note|squash|h}} The South Pacific Games Council announced in 1978 that squash would be included in the Games, and it was played in 1979, 1983, 1987, and 1991. There were four gold medals on offer in 1983, for men's and women's individual and team events. The men's individual event won by Fiji's Willie Valentine, and the women's team event won by PNG.{{sfn|SPG Results|1983|page=4}} Fiji won silver in both men's and women's team events. {{note|volleyball|i}} Women's volleyball was played at the 1983 South Pacific Games.

{{infobox football tournament season | title = Norwegian Football Cup | year = 1990 | country = {{NOR}} | num_teams = | defending champions = [[Viking FK|Viking]] | champions = [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]] | runner-up = [[Fyllingen Fotball|Fyllingen]] | matches = | goals = | champ_match_score = 1–5 | top goal scorer = | player = | prevseason = [[1989 Norwegian Football Cup|1989]] | nextseason = [[1991 Norwegian Football Cup|1991]] }} [[File:Ullevaal Stadion utenfra.jpg|thumb|right|250px|[[Ullevaal Stadion]], [[Oslo]] - venue for the [[Norwegian Cup]] final]] The '''1990 [[Norwegian Football Cup]]''' was the 85th edition of the [[Norway|Norwegian]] Football Cup. [[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]] won the Norwegian Cup. They won the final 5–1 against [[Fyllingen Fotball]]. 28 000 spectators attended [[Ullevaal Stadion]]. == Match facts == {{footballbox |date =21 October 1990 |time = |team1 =[[Fyllingen Fotball]] |score =1–5 (0–3) |report = |team2 ='''[[Rosenborg BK|Rosenborg]]''' |goals1 =[[Paul Tengs]] {{goal|89}} |goals2 = [[Karl-Petter Løken]] {{goal|13}}
[[Gøran Sørloth]]{{goal|20}}
[[Mini Jakobsen]] {{goal|28}}
[[Karl-Petter Løken]] {{goal|59}}
[[Kåre Ingebrigtsen]] {{goal|67}} |stadium =[[Ullevaal Stadion]] (13:15) |attendance =28 000 |referee =[[Arild Haugstad]] ([[Faaberg Idrettslag|Faaberg]]) |penalties1 = |penaltyscore = |penalties2 = }} '''Rosenborg's winning team''': [[Ola By Rise]] - [[Øivind Husby]], [[Trond Sollied]], [[Knut Torbjørn Eggen]], [[Trond Børge Henriksen]] - [[Kåre Ingebrigtsen]], [[Sverre Brandhaug]], [[Ørjan Berg]] ([[Runar Berg]] 80) - [[Karl-Petter Løken]] ([[Roar Strand]] 75), [[Gøran Sørloth]] and [[Mini Jakobsen]]. '''Fyllingen's team''': [[Vidar Bahus]], [[Tom Leiknes]], [[Inge Ludvigsen]], [[Per-Ove Ludvigsen]], [[Paul Tengs]] 67), [[Gunnar Ingebrigtsen]], [[Kjell Rune Pedersen]] 50), [[Hans Brandtun]], [[Dag Bergset]], [[Håkon Knutsen]], [[Asbjørn Helgeland]], [[Tor Vikenes]] and [[Ola Lyngvær]]. == External links == *[http://www.rsssf.no/1990/fcup RSSSF.no] == References == *[http://www.rbkweb.no/klubben/cupfinaler.shtml Rosenborg's website] {{Norwegian Football Cup}} {{1989–90 in European football (UEFA)}} {{1990–91 in European football (UEFA)}} [[Category:Norwegian Football Cup seasons]] [[Category:1990 domestic association football cups|Norway]] [[Category:1990 in Norwegian football|Football Cup]] {{Norway-footy-competition-stub}}

{{Infobox venue | name = Al Worthington Stadium | nickname = | image = | fullname = | former_names = Liberty Field (1979-1986), Al Worthington Field (1986-1995) | location = Wards Road, [[Lynchburg, Virginia|Lynchburg]], [[Virginia|VA]], United States | coordinates = {{coord|37.353588|-79.180379|display=title,inline}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1979 | renovated = 1999, 2000, 2003, 2006, 2008 | expanded = 2008 | closed = 2012 | demolished = 2013<ref name=demolished>{{cite web|title=Demolition at old baseball stadium makes way for new projects|url=http://www.liberty.edu/news/index.cfm?PID=18495&MID=101874|work=Liberty University News Service |accessdate=6 November 2013|date=2013-10-17}}</ref> | owner = [[Liberty University]] | operator = Liberty University | surface = [[FieldTurf]] collar around [[home plate]], [[bermuda grass]] infield (1999-present), natural [[grass]] outfield | scoreboard = Electronic | estimated_cost = | suites = Yes | architect = | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 2,500 | record_attendance = 3,183 (March 28, 2008, vs. [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball|Coastal Carolina]]) | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Liberty Flames baseball]] ([[NCAA]] [[Division I (NCAA)|DI]] [[Big South Conference|Big South]]) (1979-2012) }}
'''Al Worthington Stadium''' was a [[baseball]] [[baseball field|venue]] on the campus of [[Liberty University]] in [[Lynchburg, Virginia]], United States. It was home to the [[Liberty Flames]] of the [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] [[Big South Conference]]. Opened in 1979, the facility was named for former Liberty baseball coach and athletic director [[Al Worthington]].<ref name=facil>{{cite web|title=Worthington Stadium |url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=16988 |work=Liberty Flames |accessdate=19 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/613lTInqo?url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=16988 |archivedate=2011-08-19 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> It had a capacity of 2,500 spectators.<ref name=overview>{{cite web|title=Facilities Overview |url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=16998 |work=Liberty Flames |accessdate=19 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/613lWqfWe?url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=16998 |archivedate=2011-08-19 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Plans for a new Liberty baseball venue were announced in August 2011, and [[Liberty Baseball Stadium]] opened prior to the [[2013 NCAA Division I baseball season|2013 season]].<ref name=newvenue>{{cite web|last=Foley |first=Brian |title=Liberty set to open New Stadium for 2013 Season |url=http://www.collegebaseballdaily.com/2011/08/10/liberty-set-to-open-new-stadium-for-2013-season/ |work=College Baseball Daily |accessdate=21 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/616i7eihv?url=http://www.collegebaseballdaily.com/2011/08/10/liberty-set-to-open-new-stadium-for-2013-season/ |archivedate=2011-08-21 |date=August 10, 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Worthington Stadium was demolished in 2013.<ref name="demolished"/>
== History == The venue opened in 1979 as '''Liberty Field'''. [[Al Worthington]] was Liberty's head coach at the time. On May 3, 1986, the field was dedicated '''Al Worthington Field'''.<ref name="facil" />
In 1995, the venue's name was again changed, this time to Al Worthington Stadium. In 1998, the stadium won ''Sports Turf Magazine'''s "Diamond of the Year" award.<ref name="facil" />
Beginning in 1999, the stadium underwent a series of renovations. In that year, a 5,200 ft.² hitting complex was added, located down the [[left field]] line. Also in 1999, the [[infield]] was resurfaced with [[bermuda grass]]. A new [[PA system]] and backstop were installed in 2000. 2003 construction added an indoor hitting facility, [[luxury boxes]], and a clubhouse. Renovations completed in 2008 added stadium lighting and additional seating, which raised capacity by 600-700 spectators.<ref name="facil" />
With the addition of stadium lighting, Worthington Stadium's first night game was played on March 28, 2008.<ref name="facil" /> On the same night, the stadium set a new attendance record of 3,183 spectators.<ref name="overview" /> Liberty lost the game to [[Coastal Carolina Chanticleers baseball|Coastal Carolina]] 5-3 in 11 innings.<ref name="facil" />
In August 2011, the university announced plans for a new baseball venue. The plans called for the venue to be built near [[Williams Stadium]], the university's [[American football|football]] venue, and to hold 3,000 spectators. The project was projected to cost roughly [[USD|$]]5 million. The announcement included plans for Worthington Stadium to become a [[softball]] venue.<ref name=newvenue />
The stadium closed following the [[2012 NCAA Division I baseball season|2012 season]]. Its final game was played on May 13, 2012, in which [[High Point Panthers baseball|High Point]] defeated Liberty 13-11.<ref name=finalgame>{{cite web|title=High Point Edges Liberty in Slugfest in Final Game at Worthington |url=http://www.liberty.edu/flames/index.cfm?PID=10869&newsID=9063&TeamID=1 |work=Liberty.edu |accessdate=31 January 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E5IErT8H?url=http://www.liberty.edu/flames/index.cfm?PID=10869&newsID=9063&TeamID=1 |archivedate=31 January 2013 |date=13 May 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> It was demolished in 2013.<ref name="demolished"/>
== Naming == The venue was named for [[Al Worthington]]. Following a fourteen-season major league career, Worthington came to Liberty in 1974. As the Flames' baseball coach from 1974 to 1986, Worthington compiled a 343-189-1 record. In each of the last 12 of Worthington's 13 seasons, the program had a winning record.<ref name=worth>{{cite web|title=Al Worthington (Baseball Coach: 1974-86/Athletics Director: 1983-89) |url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=18442#Al%20Worthington |work=Liberty Flames |accessdate=19 August 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/613lfq829?url=http://www.libertyflames.com/index.cfm?PID=18442 |archivedate=2011-08-19 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
After being named Liberty's [[athletic director]] in 1983, Worthington continued to coach baseball until 1986. On May 3, 1986, Liberty's baseball field was dedicated to Worthington during his final home game as baseball coach. The Flames defeated [[Maryland Terrapins|Maryland]] 19-3.<ref name="facil" />
== References == {{Reflist}} {{Liberty University}}

The '''Australian Sports Commission Media Awards''' were established in 2002 to recognise excellence in Australian sports journalism and broadcasting. The awards focus on analytical and insightful reporting and the presentation of sport and sporting issues. The awards are the only dedicated sports media awards in Australia. The [[Walkley Awards]] do have several sports categories.{{cite web|title=ASC Media Awards 2017|url=https://www.ausport.gov.au/news/media_awards|website=Australian Sports Commission website|accessdate=3 February 2018}} The most prestigious award is the Lifetime Achievement Award that recognises exceptional service to sports journalism over an extended period of time. revision.text:
[[File:Beach Golf 2002.jpg|thumb|Beach Golf event 2002]] [[File:Pallina Beach Golf.jpg|thumb|Special Beach Golf Ball]]
'''Beach golf''' is a variation of [[golf]] mainly played on sandy beaches. It was devised with the aim of a simplified and more accessible version of golf.
The game is played along a distance of about 2 kilometres (1.2 miles) on which the players, two per team, with as few strokes as possible, have to reach the final hole, hitting a soft polyurethane ball with a classic golf club.
== History ==
Beach golf was created in [[Pescara]], Italy in 1999 by Mauro De Marco.<ref>{{Citation| title =Palla in buca...ma nella sabbia | newspaper = Abruzzo Oggi | publication-place = Pescara, Italy | date = August 19, 2005 }}</ref> It was designed to be played on crowded beaches during the summer. Objects on the beach are incorporated into the game. Beach umbrellas, bathing people and other objects are turned into obstacles of the game. The rules allow the audience to interact with participants.
The game, developed by BGSA (Beach Golf Sport Association), has been recognized by the [[Centro Sportivo Educativo Nazionale]] (National Educational Sports Centre) and by the [[Italian National Olympic Committee]].
In the summer of 2014, in [[Montesilvano]], was organized the first edition of the European Beach Golf Contest,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ilcentro.gelocal.it/pescara/cronaca/2014/09/07/news/golf-sulla-spiaggia-a-montesilvano-1.9892780|title=Golf sulla spiaggia a Montesilvano|work=il Centro}}</ref> an international event which was attended by 90 athletes representing 18 European nations.<ref>{{cite av media|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bD1ADJ5k6oI|title=European University beach golf 2014|date=2 April 2014|work=YouTube}}</ref> The 7 days of competition<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sportag.it/altri-sport/european-beach-golf-montesilvano-partenza-sprint/|title=European Beach Golf a Montesilvano: partenza sprint|author=Redazione|work=Sportag.it|access-date=2015-02-11|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150209133420/http://www.sportag.it/altri-sport/european-beach-golf-montesilvano-partenza-sprint/|archive-date=2015-02-09|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> have seen the triumph of the Irish Robert Cast, who took home the first continental title.
Notable competitions have included the Jeckerson Cup 2005 held in the [[Piazza del Campo]], [[Siena]]. The competition was held between 40 teams from different nations. Teams competed in the streets in a “We Golf” race (variant of Beach golf on the street) and were followed by a crowd of 80000 people.<ref>{{Citation | title = Nel corso e in piazza: oggi la Jeckerson Cup | newspaper = Il cittadino oggi | publication-place = Siena e Provincia, ITALY | date = June 4, 2005 }}</ref>
In the following years tours were conducted during the summer on the beaches of the Italian coast. * 2006 Italian championship departed from [[Naples]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://corrieredelmezzogiorno.corriere.it/napoli/notizie/sport/2010/7-luglio-2010/beach-golf-tour-nabilah-ma-sogno-via-partenope--1703345341745.shtml |title=Beach Golf Tour al Nabilah, ma il sogno č via Partenope - Corriere del Mezzogiorno |publisher=Corrieredelmezzogiorno.corriere.it |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> and also visited the regions of [[Calabria]].<ref>{{Citation | title = Un Beach Golf per promuovere turismo e sport sulla costa | newspaper = Gazzetta del Sud | publication-place = Calabria, ITALY | date = June 28, 2005 }}</ref> and [[Sardinia]].
* The tour of 2010, in collaboration with the [[University of Urbino]], was thirty consecutive days of events along the coast of the [[Adriatic Sea]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.uniurb.it/it/portale/index.php?mist_id=0&lang=IT&tipo=IST&page=1123&recordID=1096 |title=Università di Urbino "Carlo Bo" - Uniurb • it - Leggi Comunicato |publisher=Uniurb.it |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121224105505/http://www.uniurb.it/it/portale/index.php?mist_id=0&lang=IT&tipo=IST&page=1123&recordID=1096 |archive-date=2012-12-24 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref>
Beach golf has been discussed on an Italian national television network<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SoajP4Wy38M&list=UUtGXmnNwkx1nAIemDxTSPlQ&index=14&feature=plcp |title=tg1.mpg |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> and on [[Radio Kiss Kiss]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8AKwYRTu2Ok |title=BeachGolf & KissKiss - Intervista Marco Baldini - Mauro De Marco |publisher=YouTube |date=2009-07-21 |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref> Space was also given to Beach golf in the [[Rimini]] Wellness Fair,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.sportydoo.it/2011/05/16/beach-golf-si-gioca-in-spiaggia/ |title=Beach Golf: si gioca anche in spiaggia | Sportydoo - Blog sulle attrezzature sportive |publisher=Sportydoo.it |date=2011-05-16 |accessdate=2012-01-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110523010125/http://www.sportydoo.it/2011/05/16/beach-golf-si-gioca-in-spiaggia/ |archivedate=2011-05-23 |df= }}</ref> and Sports Day.
[[File:Beach Golf 2007.jpg|right|thumb|natural obstacles in Beach golf event 2007]]
== Rules== [[File:Beach Golf 2006.jpg|right|thumb|Swing on the beach, event 2006]] Regulations have been created for the Beach Golf Event, aiming to anticipate various kinds of situations. The main rule states that people and things constitute natural obstacles on the path.
The game takes place along a path of 2 km of sandy coastline on the beach, where 40 teams of two players each (a pro and a beginner), challenge each other to arrive at the final hole with the fewest possible strokes. The game-track is not bounded by any type of border and is punctuated by beach umbrellas and bathers that become natural obstacles throughout the competition.
Because of the crowded place where the event takes place, the ball used is made of soft [[polyurethane foam]] to prevent injury to anyone who is accidentally hit during the game. The route is accompanied throughout its track by music and entertainment that involve, in an original way, the audience that becomes active in the field of play. The range of the golfer beach is bordered by a protection zone of about 5 meters, supported by three girls on the way to accompany throughout the game.
=== Team === Each team is composed of two players, a low-handicap player and a high-handicap one. The sum of the two handicaps split approximately to the next lower (e.g.: mean 17.5, the team is hcp 17) and that is the team’s handicap that show how many improvements can benefit the team. The game is played with only one beaten ball each turn. It is admitted that the one it replaces the other, in case you lose stroke and distance. Penalty: loss of stroke and distance.
=== Scorecard === The scorecard is a table which shows the data about the team and the history of the game. It consists of nine items:
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Label !! Description |- | '''Team''' || Name of the team as well as the sponsor. |- | '''Player 1''' || Name, surname and handicap of the player with the lowest handicap in the team. |- | '''Player 2''' || Name, surname and handicap of the player with the highest handicap in the team. |- | '''Team Handicap''' || Average handicap of the team. |- | '''Score''' || All strokes played during the round. |- | '''Drop''' || All drops that took place during the round. |- | '''Penalty''' || All penalties that was incurred during the round. |- | '''Handicap''' || Strokes that can be deducted from the score. |- | '''Scorer''' || The name of the caddie girl that recorded the score. |}
=== Game === It is a stroke-game competition held in two rounds. Two types of balls are used: a soft rubber, totally harmless ( 69 mm in diameter ) which is used along the track and a regular one on the green. There is no time limit. Players have the opportunity to stop to have a lunch break, however, teams must respect the assigned starting time.
=== Track === This goes along the shore of any beach. When the Beach Golf is held in Pescara, we start from Paolucci Square and arrive at Stadium of the Sea, close to Cascella’s Ship. The track has a length of 1600 meters and a width that take the whole beach.
=== The starting area ===
The starting area is located where the first ball is hit. The area consists of a synthetic rug 1.50x1.50 m2. The ball is placed on the appropriate tee and both players choose a tee shot, placing the balls in the best possible way. The honor is given (noblesse oblige) to the lower handicap player. Any missed shot or barely touched balls are considered as a shot along the path. If the ball is dropped from the tee without being touched can be repositioned to make the shot. Each team starts three minutes after the previous one. The delay allowed is ten minutes after the departure of the next team. The laggard team start for last with a penalty of five shots.
=== Equipment === [[File:Bastoni Beach Golf.jpg|thumb|Beach Golf Clubs]]
The equipment used consist in a classic golf club, expanded foam balls and a protection belt.
==== Clubs ==== Preferably sand or wedge type.
==== Ball ====
The ball is made of polyurethane foam with a diameter of 7 cm and a weigh of 35g approximately. Its composition makes them harmless, allowing to play anywhere.
==== Protection belt ==== [[File:Fascia protezione.jpg|thumb|Protection Belt]]
This is held by the Caddy Girls and has a very important function which is to guarantee the safety of bathers, the players and anyone who is on the game-track. This is what makes the Beach Golf the only sport in the world where viewers are on the pitch and involved as active part in the game.
== Caddy Girls == Caddy Girls act both as game-judges and hostesses during the event. Their role is to ensure that the game takes place in a proper and safe way. The Caddy Girls support a protection belt around the area of action, aiming to allow the golfer to play in peace among the bathers, beach chairs and umbrellas.
The BGSA has planned a special calendar, featuring the Beach golf Caddy Girls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tshot.it/articolo/calendario-caddy-girls-2009-per-il-beach-golf/1276/ |title=Calendario Caddy Girls 2009 per il Beach Golf | Tshot |publisher=Tshot.it |date= |accessdate=2012-01-25}}</ref>
==References== {{commonscat|Beach golf}} {{Portal|sport}} {{reflist}}
== External links == * [http://www.beachgolf.net/ B.G.S.A. (Beach Golf Sport Association)] * [http://www.csen.it/ CSEN] * [http://www.federgolf.it/ FIG] * [http://www.coni.it/ CONI] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qXH2m1iOoGo/ Video about Beach Golf] on [[YouTube]]
{{Golf}}

[[Djibouti (city)]], [[Djibouti]]| capacity =| chairman = | manager = Mr Luis Colás | league = [[Djibouti Premier League]]| season = 2013–14 | position = | }} '''AS Chemin de Fer Djibouto-Ethiopien''' also known as '''AS Compagnie Djibouti-Ethiopie''', more commonly known as '''CDE-Colas''', is a [[Djbouti|Djiboutian]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club located in [[Djibouti City]], [[Djibouti]]. It currently plays in the [[Djibouti Premier League]].{{cite web|url=https://int.soccerway.com/teams/djibouti/as-du-chemin-de-fer-djibouto-ethiopien--colas/20849/matches/|title=Gibuti – AS du Chemin de Fer Djibouto-Ethiopien / Colas – Risultati e calendario – Soccerway|publisher=|accessdate=26 September 2014}} ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 40000 capacity [[Stade du Ville]]. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/djibouti/as-du-chemin-de-fer-djibouto-ethiopien--colas/20849/ Soccerway] [[Category:Football clubs in Djibouti]] {{Djibouti-sport-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Centennial Olympic Stadium | nickname = | image = Athletics venue during the 1996 Paralympic Games.jpg | caption = Interior of the stadium during the 1996 Paralympic Games | location = [[Atlanta, Georgia]], [[United States]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = July 10, 1993 | opened = May 18, 1996 | renovated = 1997 (reconstructed as [[Turner Field]])
2017 (reconstructed as [[Georgia State Stadium]]) | expanded = | closed = August 25, 1996 | demolished = | owner = Atlanta Fulton County Recreation Authority | operator = Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games | surface = [[Grass]] | Constructor = | construction_cost = $209 million{{cite news |title=At Close of Games, Braves Will Move Into Olympic Stadium|last=Sandomir|first=Richard|date=July 30, 1996|accessdate=July 24, 2008|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/specials/olympics/0730/oly-stadium-braves.html}}
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|209000000|1996}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Atlanta Stadium Design Team (a joint venture of [[Heery International|Heery International, Inc.]], [[Rosser International|Rosser International, Inc.]], Williams-Russell and Johnson, Inc. and [[Ellerbe Becket|Ellerbe Becket, Inc.]])[http://www.ellerbebecket.com/expertise/project/94/Turner_Field.html Turner Field] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090618152358/http://www.ellerbebecket.com/expertise/project/94/Turner_Field.html |date=2009-06-18 }} architect: [[Ellerbe Becket]] official site | former_names = | tenants = [[1996 Summer Olympics]]
[[1996 Summer Paralympics]] | seating_capacity = 85,000 | dimensions = }} '''Centennial Olympic Stadium''' was the 85,000-seat main [[stadium]] of the [[1996 Summer Olympic Games]] and the [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Summer Paralympic Games]] in [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]]. Construction of the stadium began in 1993, and it was complete and ready for the Opening Ceremony in July 1996, where it hosted [[Athletics at the 1996 Summer Olympics|track and field events]] and the [[1996 Summer Olympics closing ceremony|closing ceremony]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20080528011846/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v1.pdf 1996 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 1. p. 542.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070927222634/http://www.la84foundation.org/6oic/OfficialReports/1996/1996v3.pdf 1996 Summer Olympics official report.] Volume 3. p. 449. After the Olympics and Paralympics, it was reconstructed into the baseball-specific [[Turner Field]], used by the [[Atlanta Braves]] of [[Major League Baseball]] for 20 seasons (1997–2016). After the Braves departed for [[SunTrust Park]], the facility was purchased by [[Georgia State University]], which rebuilt the stadium a second time as [[Georgia State Stadium]], designed for [[American football]]. ==History== [[File:JO Atlanta 1996 - Stade.jpg|thumb|left|Stadium during the 1996 Summer Olympic Games. Seats in the background became the seating behind home plate for Turner Field and subsequently the south end zone for Georgia State Stadium.]] During the week-long athletics program, the stadium bore witness to [[Donovan Bailey]] of [[Canada]] winning the 100 m in a world record time of 9.84 s; [[Michael Johnson (athlete)|Michael Johnson]] winning both the 200 and 400 metres titles, breaking the 200 m world record in the process; and [[France]]'s [[Marie-José Pérec]] also winning the 200/400 double. Meanwhile, [[Carl Lewis]] won his fourth consecutive Olympic title in the [[long jump]], becoming only the second person, after [[Al Oerter]], to win the same athletics event at four consecutive Games. After the closing ceremony of the [[1996 Summer Paralympics|1996 Paralympics]], the stadium was officially leased by the [[Atlanta Braves]]. Private entities, including [[NBC]] and other Olympic sponsors, agreed to pay a large sum of the cost to build Centennial Olympic Stadium (approximately $170 million of the $209 million bill). The [[Atlanta Committee for the Olympic Games]] (ACOG) sought to build the stadium in a way that it could be converted to a new baseball stadium, and ACOG paid for the conversion.{{cite news|title=At Close of Games, Braves Will Move Into Olympic Stadium |last=Sandomir |first=Richard |date=1996-07-30 |accessdate=2008-07-24 |work=The New York Times |publisher=The New York Times Company |url=https://www.nytimes.com/specials/olympics/0730/oly-stadium-braves.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080628184724/http://www.nytimes.com/specials/olympics/0730/oly-stadium-braves.html |archivedate=2008-06-28 |deadurl=yes |df= }} This was considered a good agreement for both the Olympic Committee and the Braves, because there would be no use for a permanent 85,000 seat [[track and field]] stadium in [[Downtown Atlanta]] since the 71,000 seat [[Georgia Dome]] had been completed 4 years earlier by the state of Georgia and became the home of the [[National Football League]]'s [[Atlanta Falcons]]. The Braves had already been exploring opportunities for a new venue to replace [[Atlanta–Fulton County Stadium]]. The southwest corner of the Olympic Stadium was built to accommodate the future baseball [[Infielder|infield]] and seating. This is easily seen in aerial views and diagrams of the stadium in its Olympic configuration, where the seats are not placed next to the [[Track and field|oval running track]]. The southwest part of the stadium also had four tiers of seats, [[luxury box]]es, a facade facing the street, and a roof, whereas the north half of the stadium used a simpler two-tiered seating configuration. During reconstruction, the [[All-weather running track|athletics track]] was removed and relocated to [[Panther Stadium|the field hockey stadium]] located at [[Clark Atlanta University]], which uses it for athletics and [[American football|football]], and the north half of the stadium was [[demolish]]ed, reducing the capacity to 49,000. Because of the need to fit a track within the stadium in its earlier incarnation, the field of play, particularly foul territory, while not large by historical standards, was nonetheless larger than that of most MLB stadiums built since 1990. Reconstruction was complete in 1997, and the facility was renamed [[Turner Field]]. Afterward, Atlanta–Fulton County Stadium, the Braves' previous home and the venue for the Olympics baseball events, was [[building implosion|imploded]] and the site became a parking lot for Turner Field. The Atlanta Fulton County Recreation Authority owned Turner Field, and the Atlanta Braves occupied the revised stadium until the expiration of their lease in 2016; the Braves moved to [[SunTrust Park]] in [[Cobb County, Georgia|Cobb County]] in the following year.{{cite web |title=Turner Field |first=Scott |last=Kendrick |work=About.com |publisher=The New York Times Company |url=http://baseball.about.com/od/photogalleries/ig/MLB-Stadiums-Gallery/Turner-Field.htm |accessdate=2008-07-24}} Georgia State University acquired Turner Field and its surrounding parking lots in January 2017 for a mixed use expansion of the Georgia State campus, which includes private and student housing, academic, retail, and office space in addition to the redevelopment of the former ballpark into Georgia State Stadium. The [[Atlanta Track Club]]'s annual Father's Day four-mile (6.4 km) road race ends inside the stadium near the warning track where the finish line was located for the Olympics.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Centennial Olympic Stadium}} *[http://www.andrewclem.com/Baseball/TurnerField.html Interactive diagram at Clem's Baseball site showing both Olympic and Braves configurations] *[http://newsimg.bbc.co.uk/media/images/44222000/jpg/_44222953_atlanta416.jpg Aerial View of Olympic Stadium] *[http://richardweisser.com/photoman80.htm Reconstruction into Baseball Stadium] *[http://olympics.ballparks.com/1996Atlanta/index.htm 1996 Summer Games] {{s-start}} {{succession box | before = [[Estadi Olímpic Lluís Companys|Estadi Olímpic de Montjuïc]]
[[Barcelona, Spain|Barcelona]] | title = [[Summer Olympics]]
[[1996 Summer Olympics opening ceremony|Opening]] and Closing Ceremonies ([[Olympic Stadium]]) | years = [[1996 Summer Olympics|1996]] | after = [[Stadium Australia]]
[[Sydney]] }} {{succession box | before = [[Estadi Olímpic Lluís Companys|Estadi Olímpic de Montjuïc]]
[[Barcelona, Spain|Barcelona]] | title = [[Athletics at the Summer Olympics|Olympic Athletics competitions]]

[[Sydney]] }} {{s-end}} {{Atlanta landmarks}} {{Summer Olympic stadia}} {{1996 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues athletics}} {{coord|33|44|08|N|84|23|22|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Olympic stadiums|Atlanta]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Venues of the 1996 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:Olympic athletics venues]] [[Category:Defunct athletics (track and field) venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Atlanta]] [[Category:1996 establishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:1997 disestablishments in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Defunct sports venues in Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 1997]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Corrigan Park | nickname = '''{{lang|ga|Pairc Uí Chorragáin}}''' | image = | location = Whiterock Road, [[Belfast]], [[Northern Ireland]] | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1926 | opened = 1927 | renovated = 2001 | surface = | owner = [[St. John's GAA (Belfast)|St John's GAC]] | operator = | architect = | cost = | capacity = 5,000 | dimensions = }} '''Corrigan Park''' is a GAA ground on the Whiterock Road in West Belfast that served as the main venue for Gaelic Games in Belfast until the opening of [[Casement Park]] in 1953. It is named in honour of Sean Corrigan, mentor of the Brian Óg club who were [[Antrim GAA|Antrim]]’s first hurling champions. It is designated as a ground with a capacity of 5,000 by [[Belfast City Council]].<ref>[http://www.belfastcity.gov.uk/healthandsafety/sportsgrounds.asp Belfast City Council Health & Safety]</ref>
==Current== It is home to [[St. John's GAA (Belfast)|St John's GAC]]. It regularly hosts Ulster club<ref>http://www.independent.ie/sport/mcconville-goals-decisive-430028.html 1998 Oct 12 McConville Goals Decisive]</ref> and colleges matches at second<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/sport/saints-sights-on-mcrory-glory-415198.html 1991 Ulster colleges final]</ref> and third<ref>[http://www.independent.ie/sport/sportslines-477789.html Sigerson 2004 Queen's Univ 1-7 Sligo IT report]</ref> level.
==History==
===Hurling===
Corrigan Park was associated with the run of the Antrim hurling team to the final of the [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship 1943|1943]] All Ireland [[All-Ireland Senior Hurling Championship|championship]], Corrigan Park staged the quarter final in which Antrim beat [[Galway GAA|Galway]] and the semi-final in which Antrim beat [[Kilkenny GAA|Kilkenny]], both unexpected results at the time. Its tight, confined space was regarded as being advantageous to the home side in those matches.<ref>{{cite book | last = Corry | first = Eoghan | title = Illustrated History of the GAA | publisher = Gill & MacMillan | year = 2005 | location = Dublin, Ireland | pages = 250 }}</ref>
===Football=== Among the major football championship matches it staged were the [[Cavan GAA|Cavan]]-Antrim Ulster championship semi-finals of 1930, 1931 and 1949. Its last major football championship match was Antrim v [[Donegal GAA|Donegal]] in the Ulster championship of 1952.
===Camogie===
Corrigan Park staged the [[All-Ireland Senior Camogie Championship|All Ireland Camogie finals]] of 1944, 1946, and 1947, two of which were won by Antrim, and also several of Antrim’s semi-finals. It became known as the home of camogie during this period.<ref>The Evolution of the GAA by [[Donal McAnallen]] (Ulster Historical Foundation 2009) {{ISBN|978-1-903688-83-0}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.naomheoinclg.com/] St John's website

{{use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Darren Sammy National Cricket Stadium | nickname = | image = Beausejour_Stadium_Cricket_St_Lucia.jpg | caption = Daren Sammy Cricket Ground (previously Beausejour Cricket Ground). | country = West Indies | location = [[Gros Islet]], [[Saint Lucia]] | establishment = 2002 | seating_capacity = 15,000 | coordinates = {{coord|14|04|14.00|N|60|55|53.95|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | tenants = [[Windward Islands cricket team|Windward Islands]]
[[St Lucia Stars]] | end1 = Pavilion End | end2 = Media Centre End | international = true | firsttestdate = 20–24 June | firsttestyear = 2003 | firsttesthome = West Indies | firsttestaway = Sri Lanka | lasttestdate = 14–18 June | lasttestyear = 2018 | lasttesthome = West Indies | lasttestaway = Sri Lanka | firstodidate = 8 June | firstodiyear = 2002 | firstodihome = West Indies | firstodiaway = New Zealand | lastodidate = 9 June | lastodiyear = 2017 | lastodihome = West Indies | lastodiaway = Afghanistan | firstt20idate = 1 May | firstt20iyear = 2010 | firstt20ihome = Afghanistan | firstt20iaway = India | lastt20idate = 27 May | lastt20iyear = 2012 | lastt20ihome = West Indies | lastt20iaway = Australia | year1 = 2003 – present | club1 = [[Windward Islands cricket team|Windward Islands]] | year2 = 2013 – present | club2 = [[St Lucia Zouks]] | date = 14 June | year = 2018 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/westindies/content/ground/59518.html Cricinfo }} The '''Darren Sammy National Cricket Stadium''', previously the '''Beausejour Cricket Ground''', is a [[cricket]] ground located near [[Gros Islet]], [[Saint Lucia]] standard seating capacity of 15,000. It was completed in 2002 and currently accommodates 13,000 spectators. Originally named after the Beausejour hills[http://content-www.cricinfo.com/wc2007/content/ground/59518.html Cricinfo – Grounds – Beausejour Stadium, Gros Islet, St Lucia] and situated in the outskirts of [[Rodney Bay]], the stadium was completed in 2002 and hosts domestic matches for the [[Windward Islands cricket team]]. It staged its first international Test match in 2003 against Sri Lanka and became the first venue in the Caribbean to host a day-night game. The sporting facility was constructed on 22 acres consisting of about 18 hospitality suites and a pavilion that offers each team its own gym and lounge apart from a balcony and conference room. It is located in the driest area of Saint Lucia, making it most suitable for hosting cricket. On July 21, 2016 it was formally renamed the Darren Sammy Cricket Ground after [[Darren Sammy]] who captained the West Indies side in winning the [[2016 ICC World Twenty20]] in [[India]]. He also captained the West Indies to victory in the [[2012 ICC World Twenty20]] in [[Sri Lanka]], making him the second West Indian captain after [[Clive Lloyd]] with multiple ICC world championships. One of the stands will also be named in honour of [[Johnson Charles]], who was also part of the side in both 2012 and 2016. http://www.stlucianewsonline.com/breaking-news-beausejour-stadium-officially-renamed-darren-sammy-national-cricket-ground/[http://www.espncricinfo.com/westindies/content/story/995351.html St Lucia renames stadium in honour of Daren Sammy] The first international match played at the renamed ground took place on 9 August 2016, when [[Indian cricket team in the West Indies in 2016|India played the West Indies]] as part of a four-match Test series.{{cite web |url=http://www.espncricinfo.com/westindies/content/story/1022583.html |title=India to tour West Indies for seven weeks starting July 6 |accessdate=2 June 2016 |work=ESPN Cricinfo}} ==Location== The cricket ground is located at the north-eastern end of the tourist resort of [[Rodney Bay]], approximately 6 minutes drive from the town of [[Gros Islet]] on the scenic Castries-Gros Islet Highway. The stadium is close to the residential enclaves in Beauséjour and Epouge Bay. ==Facilities== [[File:Beausejour Cricket Ground.jpg|thumb|Main stand.]] The cricket ground is known for its high standard facilities and is regarded by the [[West Indies Cricket Board]] as a standard for current and future venues in the Caribbean.http://www.espncricinfo.com/ci/content/story/117724.html Its outfield, a perfect oval, is predictably lush green. It also became the first international ground in the Caribbean to receive floodlighting with the installation of 6 floodlight towers in 2006, enabling the hosting of day/night matches. In May 2006 it hosted the first ever international Day/Night ODI match in the Caribbean when the West Indies took on Zimbabwe. Due to the unfavourable time zone differences between the Caribbean and the large cricket markets in the far east international day/night matches have been few and far between. The facility has 18 hospitality suites, a permanent seating capacity of 13,000 with bucket-type seating which can be increased to 20,000 for international matches. There are also two artificial pitches and two turfs for practice and warm-ups. ==Ground statistics== {{main|List of international cricket centuries at the Darren Sammy National Cricket Stadium}} ===Regional cricket=== *It serves as a home venue for the [[Windward Islands cricket team]] along with the [[Mindoo Philip Park]] in [[Castries]]. ===International cricket=== *It is a home and venue in all forms of cricket for the [[West Indian cricket team|West Indies]] since 2003. ===Cricket records=== [[File:Beausejour Stadium hosting a cricket match.jpg|thumb|The stadium from the side stands.]] * First [[One Day International]]: West Indies vs [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] on 8 June 2002. * First [[Test cricket|Test match]]: West Indies vs [[Sri Lankan cricket team|Sri Lanka]] on 20–24 June 2003. *Highest team score (in Tests)- India (588–8) vs West Indies in 2006. *Highest team total (in ODIs) – New Zealand( 363–5) vs Canada in 2007. *Highest team total (in T20Is) – Australia (197–7) vs Pakistan in 2010. *Best Bowling (in ODIs) – [[Rashid Khan (cricketer)|Rashid Khan]] (7/18) vs West Indies in 2017. ==2007 Cricket World Cup== It was one of the venues of the [[2007 Cricket World Cup]], the most important tournament in international cricket, hosting 7 matches, including all 6 Group C matches. [[New Zealand cricket team|New Zealand]] went the round unbeaten, twice scoring a total beyond 300 runs. The second semi-final between the defending champions [[Australian cricket team|Australia]] and [[South African cricket team|South Africa]] was played here with an official attendance of 13,875.[http://content-usa.cricinfo.com/wc2007/engine/current/match/247506.html Cricinfo – 2nd Semi-Final: Australia v South Africa at Gros Islet, Apr 25, 2007] ===Group matches=== {{Cricket Match [[n:2007 Cricket World Cup: Kenya vs Canada|(scorecard)]] | venue = Beausejour Stadium, [[Gros Islet Quarter|Gros Islet]], [[Saint Lucia]] }} {{Cricket Match Summary | date = 16 March 2007 | team1 = Zealand|(scorecard)]] | venue = Beausejour Stadium, [[Gros Islet Quarter|Gros Islet]], [[Saint Lucia]] }} {{Cricket Match Summary | date = 18 March 2007 | team1 = {{cr-rt|England}} | score1 = 279/6 World Cup - 2nd Semi-Final: Australia vs South Africa|Scorecard]] | venue = Beausejour Stadium, [[Gros Islet Quarter|Gros Islet]], [[Saint Lucia]] }} ==2010 World Twenty20== In 2010, the stadium hosted 10 matches of the [[2010 ICC World Twenty20]] along with two other stadiums in Caribbean. Four of the matches were Group stage games, four Super 8 matches and both semi-finals of the tournament (one of the semi-finals due to bad weather preventing matches from being held at the [[Providence Stadium]] in [[Guyana]]). The stadium saw the third international Twenty20 century scored by Indian batsman [[Suresh Raina]] in the Group match between [[Indian cricket team|India]] and [[South African cricket team|South {{Expand Ukrainian|Донбас Арена|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox stadium | name = Donbass Arena | nickname = | image = 2014. Донбасс Арена (14072322363).jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = '''[[UEFA stadium categories|UEFA Category 4 Stadium]]'''
{{rating|4|4}} | | former_names = | location = [[Donetsk]], [[Ukraine]] | coordinates = {{Coord|48|1|15|N|37|48|35|E}} | broke_ground = June 27, 2006 | built = | opened = August 29, 2009 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = 2014 (due to [[War in Donbass]]) | demolished = | owner = [[Shakhtar Donetsk]] | operator = Donbass Arena | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | construction_cost = [[Hryvnia|₴]] 3,175 billion | suites = | architect = [[Arup Group Limited#Sports|Arup Sports]][http://www.arup.com/Projects/FC_Shakhtar_Stadium.aspx Official data of stadium issued by arup] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/65fo49HYF?url=http://www.arup.com/Projects/FC_Shakhtar_Stadium.aspx |date=2012-02-23 }} | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = [[Enka İnşaat ve Sanayi A.Ş.|ENKA]] | main_contractors = | capacity = 52,187 | record_attendance = | dimensions = 105m x 68m | tenants = [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk|Shakhtar Donetsk]] (2009–2014) }} '''Donbass Arena''' or '''Donbas Arena''' ({{lang-uk|Донба́с Аре́на}} {{IPA-uk|donˈbɑs ɑˈrɛnɑ|}}, {{lang-ru|Донба́сc Аре́на}}) is a stadium with a natural grass pitch in [[Donetsk]], [[Ukraine]] (under occupation by the [[Donetsk People's Republic]]) that opened on 29 August 2009. The facility is located in the center of the city, in the [[Lenin Comsomol park]]. With a capacity of 52,518 spectators, the stadium used to host [[FC Shakhtar Donetsk]] matches and hosted some matches of [[Euro 2012]]. The final cost of construction for Donbass Arena was $400M.[http://donbass-arena.com/en/news/?id=9922 Donbass Arena Ready to Open][http://euro2012-ukraine.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=3 Donbass Arena: More than Elite] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110104080824/http://euro2012-ukraine.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=1&Itemid=3 |date=January 4, 2011 }} The stadium has been closed since 2014 due to the [[War in Donbass]]. The name of the stadium represents the simplified and shortened name of the [[Donets Basin]] - huge industrial region of Donbas, hence – '''D'''on'''b'''as (in Ukrainian language: ''Донецький басейн'' or ''Донбас''). ==Construction and design== [[File:UA Donezk Zentralstadion-Schachtar Neubau.jpg|thumb|250px|Construction site in August 2007]] Construction began in 2006. The general contractor was a Turkish company ENKA. The Stadium was completed and opened in 2009. About 1600 specialists, mainly Turkish, were involved in the construction. Donbass Arena was designed by ArupSport. It was Project Managed by Arup Major Projects (Project Director Charles Goddard). Arup Sport also designed the [[City of Manchester Stadium]] (Manchester, England), [[Allianz Arena]] (Munich, Germany) and the [[Beijing National Stadium]] (Beijing, China). The soaring roof effect makes the Stadium resemble a flying saucer. The stadium has an oval shape and a glazed façade and is located near [[RSC Olimpiyskiy|Regional Sport Complex Olimpiyskiy]]. The roof of the stadium slopes from north to south matching the landscape and contributing to the natural lighting and airing of the pitch. The external lighting makes the Stadium shine at night. A major design consideration was the ongoing protection of as much of the forest setting as possible (each tree having been planted in commemoration of deceased family members in the Great Patriotic War, and the exclusion zones to the neighbouring war memorials. A major geotechnical fault exists some 100m below the ground directly under the centre-spot. The building's foundations and piling was a major sub-project. ==Opening== The Donbass Arena was completed ahead of schedule, but the grand opening was delayed until 29 August 2009 to coincide with the Ukrainian holiday of Miners Day, as well as Donetsk City day. Donetsk is in the Donbass region, a mining region, and the date was chosen for its symbolism. The primary tenant of the facility is football club [[Shakhtar Donetsk]] ("Donetsk Coal Miners"). American Pop/R&B singer-songwriter [[Beyoncé Knowles]] performed a show from her [[I Am... Tour]] on the opening night of the new stadium. It was Knowles' first performance in Ukraine.[http://www.kyivpost.com/guide/46234 Beyonce to perform at the opening of Donbass Arena] Beyoncé performed her famous hit [[Halo (Beyoncé Knowles song)|Halo]] to honour the memory of [[Michael Jackson]], who would have had his birthday on that day. Many state officials attended the show designed by K-events Filmmaster Group. The opening ceremony was awarded as ''Event of the Year'' at the [[Stadium Business Awards]] on June 18, 2010 in [[Dublin]]. Shakhtar Donetsk's first match at the stadium was a 4–0 victory in a [[Ukrainian Premier League]] [[Ukrainian Premier League 2009-10|2009–10]] Round 8 fixture on 27 September 2009 against [[FC Obolon Kyiv]].[http://www.uefa.com/competitions/uefacup/news/kind=1/newsid=880944.html New Shakhtar stadium opens doors] The first international game took place on November 18, 2009 against [[Greece national football team|Greece]], which [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]] lost 0–1 failing to qualify for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Second Round|2010 FIFA World Cup]]. ==UEFA Euro 2012 matches== Donbass Arena was included in the official bidding project submitted by Poland and Ukraine for hosting [[UEFA Euro 2012]]. The stadium was one of the venues for the UEFA Euro 2012. The stadium hosted group D stage games and one quarter-final and one semi-final game (with the other matches in that group played at [[Olimpiysky National Sports Complex|Kiev Olympic Stadium]]). Unlike most new stadiums being built in Poland and Ukraine, Donbass Arena was not specifically built for the tournament. The following matches were played at the stadium during the UEFA Euro 2012: {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="70%" |- !Date !Time ([[Central European Summer Time|CEST]] / [[EEST]]) !Team #1 !Res. !Team #2 !Round !Scored |- |2012-06-11||18.00 / 19.00||{{fb|FRA}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–1||{{fb|ENG}}||[[UEFA Euro 2012 Group D|Group D]]||style="text-align:center;"|[[Joleon Lescott]]
[[Samir Nasri]] |- |2012-06-15||18.00 / 19.00||{{fb|FRA}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|UKR}}||[[UEFA Euro 2012 Group D|Group D]]||style="text-align:center;"|[[Jérémy Ménez]]
[[Yohan Cabaye]] |- |2012-06-19||20.45 / 21.45||{{fb|ENG}}||style="text-align:center;"|1–0||{{fb|UKR}}||[[UEFA Euro 2012 Group D|Group D]]||style="text-align:center;"|[[Wayne Rooney]] |- |2012-06-23||20.45 / 21.45||{{fb|ESP}}||style="text-align:center;"|2–0||{{fb|FRA}}||[[UEFA Euro 2012 knockout stage#Spain vs France|Quarter-final]]||style="text-align:center;"|[[Xabi Alonso]] (2) |- |2012-06-27||20.45 / 21.45||{{fb|POR}} ||style="text-align:center;"|
0–0 [[Extra time|aet]]
(2–4 [[Penalty shootout (association football)|pen]].)
||{{fb|ESP}}||[[UEFA Euro 2012 knockout stage#Semi-finals|Semi-final]]||style="text-align:center;"|— |- |} ==Other uses== [[File:Donezk Donbass Arena 37.JPG|thumb|Merchandise in the Shakhtar shop]] [[File:Ultras in the Donbas Arena, 2009.JPG|thumb|Shakhtar Ultras in the stadium]] The project of new stadium "Donbass Arena" was conceived long before Ukraine was named as co-host of [[Euro 2012]]. The [[Rinat Akhmetov|owner]] considered the possibility of daily use of the arena. "Donbass Arena" includes three restaurants, a lounge-bar, a fan cafe, fast-food outlets, retail outlets, a fitness center, corporate boxes and first aid rooms. The stadium also provides facilities for corporate events - presentations, press conferences, celebrations and concerts. Stadium [[tours]] are available which include an examination of the unique features of Donbass Arena, a visit to the footballers’ rooms and FC Shakhtar Museum and a visit to the FC Shakhtar brand shop for [[souvenirs]]. ==2014 conflict in Ukraine== On 20 May 2014 the stadium hosted a small "Peace March" against the violence of the [[2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine]] and the [[self-proclaimed]] [[Donetsk People's Republic]].[https://news.pn/en/politics/104499 Akhmetov called a strike at the enterprises in protest], Ukrainian Media Group (20 May 2014)
[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27483719 Ukrainian tycoon Rinat Akhmetov confronts rebellion], [[BBC News]] (20 May 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/205611.html Akhmetov's "Peace March" in Donetsk took 20 minutes], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 May 2014)
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/205526.html Businessman Akhmetov condemns 'genocide of Donbas,' calls for peaceful rally against 'Donetsk People's Republic'], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (20 May 2014) On 22 August 2014 the stadium was damaged by what was reported to be artillery shelling, as the Ukrainian armed forces clashed with pro-Russian separatists for control of the town.[https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/champions-league-shakhtar-stadium-hit-explosions-122728614--sow.html Champions League - Shakhtar stadium hit by explosions] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826120222/https://uk.eurosport.yahoo.com/news/champions-league-shakhtar-stadium-hit-explosions-122728614--sow.html |date=2014-08-26 }} On 20 October 2014 the stadium was again damaged by what was reported to be artillery shelling. The stadium sustained damage to the east and west sides and at least one large glass panel fell near a young girl.[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-29716678 Near miss for young girl at Donetsk stadium as blast hits] Due to the ongoing conflict in Donetsk, Shakhtar moved all home games to [[Lviv]] (in the west) in 2014 before moving to the [[Metalist Oblast Sports Complex|Metalist Stadium]] in [[Kharkiv]] (183 miles to the north of Donetsk) in early 2017.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/dcunited/still-in-exile-shakhtar-donetsk-picks-new-home/2017/01/30/6e1f075c-e6f4-11e6-903d-9b11ed7d8d2a_story.html Still in exile, Shakhtar Donetsk picks new home], [[The Washington Post]] (30 January 2017) Additionally, the club's administrative headquarters and player training sessions have been shifted to Kiev.[https://www.bbc.com/sport/0/football/29694885 Shakhtar Donetsk's Donbass Arena damaged by shelling] Despite the conflict, the stadium is slowly being repaired. On 31 May 2018, the field turf was successfully restored.{{cite web |title=«Donbass Arena's» field turf was restored in Donetsk |url=http://rusvesna.su/news/1527745202 |website=rusvesna.su |accessdate=23 June 2018 |language=ru-RU}}{{rs|date=October 2018}} ==Facts== * {{convert|7668|m²|sqft|0|abbr=on}} natural turf will be used with {{convert|2201|m²|sqft|0|abbr=on}} synthetic turf * The total area of the construction site (including mobilization areas) is 254,907 m² * The land (including pitch), where the Stadium is located, is 46,780 m² * The height of the new stadium is 54m from pitch level to the top of the roof. * There are 227 lavatories with 471 toilets and 333 wash basins. * Over 120,000 m³ of concrete were poured during construction of the Stadium * Approximately 4,300 tonnes of steel were used for construction * Approximately 3,800 tonnes of steel were used for the roof structure. * Total glazing area is approximately 24,000 m² * The total area of the tiers is approximately 70,000 m² * The size of the football field is {{convert|105|x|68|m|ft|0|abbr=on}} {{clear}} {{portal|Association football|Ukraine}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20080924084136/http://donbass-arena.com/en/ Donbass Arena official website] * [http://shakhtar.com/en/news/7574 Rinat Akhmetov: The new stadium's name is Donbass Arena] {{FC Shakhtar Donetsk}} {{Euro 2012 stadiums}} {{Venues of Ukrainian PL}} {{Ukrainian crisis navbox}} [[Category:FC Shakhtar Donetsk]] [[Category:Football venues in Donetsk Oblast]] [[Category:UEFA Euro 2012 stadiums in Ukraine]] [[Category:Sport in Donetsk]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2009]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Donetsk]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Donetsk Oblast]] [[Category:SCM Holdings]] [[Category:Sports venues in Donetsk Oblast]]

/* O-Mok-See */Edited the word “costume” referring to the clothes of American Indian peoples. Costumes are a performance, an act. Calling it costume is ultimately disrespectful. Clothes/attire is who you are.
revision.text:
{{About|Equestrian games|other uses|Gymkhana (disambiguation)}} {{refimprove|date=September 2013}} '''Gymkhana''' is an [[equestrianism|equestrian]] event consisting of speed pattern racing and timed games for riders on [[horse]]s. These events often emphasize children's participation and may be organized by a recognized [[Pony Club]] or a [[4-H]] club. In parts of the western United States, this type of competition is usually called an "'''O-Mok-See'''" (also spelled "omoksee" or without hyphenation as "o mok see") competition, a term derived from a [[Native Americans in the United States|Native American]] phrase said to mean "games on horseback." Very small events with little or no prize money, designed for beginners or riders at a local level, are sometimes called '''playdays'''. Gymkhana is the word used in most of the rest of the English-speaking world, including the United Kingdom, and both the east and west coasts of the United States.
== Types of events ==
Gymkhana and o-mok-see classes include timed speed events such as [[barrel racing]], [[pole bending]], [[keyhole race]], keg race (also known as "down and back"), [[Flag Racing|flag racing]], and stake race. Some organizations include ride and run, musical mats, egg stomp, $1 bill race or "ride a buck", and sack race.
Most of these events are designed to display precise, controlled actions and tight teamwork between horse and rider at speed, and demonstrate many skills such as [[flying change|flying lead chang]]es, sliding stops and more. Most clubs offer a variety of classes for all ages and abilities of people, allowing riders to compete at the speed level at which they are most capable and comfortable.
==O-Mok-See== O-Mok-See or omoksee is the most common term used in the Western United States for events in the sport of pattern horse racing. Most events are run with contestants simultaneously running in 4 separate lanes (3 for small arenas), with each contestant riding in a 30 foot wide lane. The origin of the term "O-Mok-See" is thought to specifically originate with the [[Blackfoot Confederacy|Blackfeet]] people where they described a particular style of riding as "oh-mak-see pass-kan" meaning "riding big dance". This event was thought to be a war ceremony; before setting out on a mounted expedition against the enemy, the warriors of the camp performed this dance as a part of the prelude of stirring up courage and enthusiasm for battle. The warriors put on their finest dress attire, decorated and painted their best horses, carrying their war bundles, shields, lances and bonnets. They mounted and gathered at some distance out of sight of the camp. They turned and rode together at full speed into the great camp circle, circled around it once and then rode to the center of the camp. In the center were a number of old men and women who sang special songs and beat drums for the horsemen. The horsemen then rode their trained horses to the rhythm of the singers and drummers. From time to time the riders dismounted and danced about on foot beside their horses, shooting in the air and shouting to one another to be brave when the battle came. If anyone fell from his horse during the ceremony it was considered an omen of bad luck.
===National Saddle Clubs Association=== The National Saddle Clubs Association (NSCA) was established in January 1965 as the first national organization of saddle clubs. The NSCA held its first national championship show in 1966. The NSCA has adopted and promotes the sport of "pattern horse racing" under the term O-Mok-See. They encourage and allow families to compete together. The NSCA has adopted a set of pattern horse racing events for national competition . some of the events that they run are pole bending, California stake race, polo, key, international flags, Idaho figure-eight and two barrel Flags. There are also 10 or so more events in their rule book. Through standardized rules and regulations for pattern horse racing events, the NSCA's prime purpose and objectives are to promote and cultivate cooperation and friendly relationships between saddle clubs throughout the United States.
==See also== *[[Gymkhana (motorsport)]] *[[Horse show]] *[[Pony Club]] *[[Rodeo]] *[[Mounted games]] *[[Tent pegging]] *[[Gymkhana]] -- for information on sporting clubs in India, from which the term originally derived.
==External links== *[http://www.omoksee.org/ National Saddle Clubs Association (USA). Official sanctioning body for O-Mok-See competition in the United States] *History retrieved from NSCA website: http://www.omoksee.org/nsca/nsca.html *http://www.calgymkhana.com/ The California Gymkhana Association (CGA) {{Equestrian Sports}} [[Category:Physical exercise]] [[Category:Mounted games]] [[Category:Western-style riding]]

{{Infobox field hockey club | clubname = HGC | image = | caption = | fullname = HOC Gazellen Combinatie | nickname = | founded = {{Start date and age|1906|09|22|df=y}} | dissolved = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | ground = | capacity = | chairman = | owner = | coach = [[Paul van Ass]] | captain = | main sponsor = [[ABN-AMRO]] | kit manufacturer = Indian Maharadja | members = 1336<ref>{{cite web |title=HGC |url=https://www.knhb.nl/clubs/hgc |accessdate=2 June 2018 |language=Dutch |date=31 October 2017}}</ref> | league = Hoofdklasse | website = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} --> | kit_alt1 = | pattern_la1 = _blackborder | pattern_b1 = _collarblack | pattern_ra1 = _blackborder | pattern_sh1 = | pattern_so1 = _2 black stripes | leftarm1 = 87CEFA | body1 = 87CEFA | rightarm1 = 87CEFA | shorts1 = 000000 | socks1 = 87CEFA | kit_alt2 = | pattern_la2 = _carolinaborder | pattern_b2 = | pattern_ra2 = _carolinaborder | pattern_sh2 = | pattern_so2 = _band_blue | leftarm2 = 000000 | body2 = 000000 | rightarm2 = 000000 | shorts2 = 000000 | socks2 = 000000 | kit_alt3 = | pattern_la3 = | pattern_b3 = | pattern_ra3 = | pattern_sh3 = | pattern_so3 = | pattern_name3 = | leftarm3 = | body3 = | rightarm3 = | shorts3 = | socks3 = }}
'''H.O.C. Gazellen-Combinatie''', also known as '''HGC''', is a [[field hockey]] club located in [[Wassenaar]] on the border of [[The Hague]] in the [[Netherlands]]. The club was founded on 22 September 1906.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.hgc.nl/|title=HGC official website site|accessdate=2015-01-31}}</ref>
The first teams (men and women) competed for many years on the highest level of the Dutch field hockey league, in the "Hoofdklasse". In 1995/'96 both the men's and the women's first team won the national championship. The men's 1st XI also compete in the [[Euro Hockey League]].
HGC has produced a number of internationals for the Dutch national teams as well as attracting a number of internationals from other countries.
==Honours==
===Men=== '''Dutch national title: 2''' *1990, 1996 '''[[EuroHockey Club Champions Cup|European Cup]]: 1''' *1997 '''[[EuroHockey Cup Winners Cup|Cup Winners' Cup]]: 2''' *1992, 1993 '''[[Euro Hockey League]]: 1''' *[[Euro Hockey League 2010-11|2011]] '''Dutch national title indoor hockey: 4''' *1986, 1993, 1996, 1998
===Women=== '''Dutch national title: 8''' *1982, 1985, 1986, 1988, 1990, 1993, 1996, 1997 '''KNHB Cup: 1''' *1996 '''[[EuroHockey Club Champions Cup|European Cup]]: 7''' *1983, 1984, 1985, 1986, 1987, 1991, 1994 '''[[EuroHockey Cup Winners Cup|Cup Winners' Cup]]: 1''' *1993 '''Dutch national title indoor hockey: 5''' *1982, 1984, 1986, 1987, 2003, 2004
==Internationals past and present== {{columns-list|colwidth=22em| * [[Helen van der Ben]] * [[Carina Benninga]] * [[Roderik Bouwman]] * [[Ronald Brouwer]] * [[Phillip Burrows]] - New Zealand * [[Marc Delissen]] * [[Robbert Delissen]] * [[Willemijn Duyster]] * [[Simon Egerton]] - England and GB * [[Rodrigo Garza]] - Spain * [[Noor Holsboer]] * [[Eric-Jan Iding]] * [[Ashley Jackson (field hockey)|Ashley Jackson]] - England and GB * [[John Jermyn (field hockey)|John Jermyn]] * [[Wouter Leefers]] * [[Lisanne Lejeune]] * [[Iain Lewers]] - England and GB * [[Bram Lomans]] * [[Tycho van Meer]] * [[Fatima Moreira de Melo]] * [[Barry Middleton]] - England and GB * [[Jan Willem Neuberg]] * [[Wietske de Ruiter]] * [[Florentine Steenberghe]] * [[Stephan Veen]] * [[Ellis Verbakel]] * [[Guus Vogels]] * [[Gijs Weterings]] * [[Suzan van der Wielen]] * [[Laurien Willemse]] * [[David Yule (field hockey)|David Yule]] - Canada }}Stephane Jaquet - France * [[Jorrit Croon]] * [[Floris van der Linden (hockeyer)]] * [[Tristan Algera]] * [[Seve van Ass]] * [[Sam van der Ven]] * [[Gonzalo Peillat]] - Argentina * [[Joaquín Menini]] - Argentina * [[Lucas Vila]] - Argentina * [[Bosco Pérez-Pla]] - Spain * [[Álvaro Iglesias (field hockey)]] - Spain * [[Rob Short]] - Canada * [[Simon Mantell]] - England and GB * [[Ken Pereira]] - Canada

{{Fieldhockey-team-stub}} {{Netherlands-sport-stub}}

'''Jokari''' is a game principally for two players, but it can also be played solo. The game consists of a rubber ball attached to an anchor by means of a long elastic band, which makes the ball come back when you hit it. Jokari is played with wooden paddles.
The jokari was invented in France in 1938, by Louis Joseph Miremont, then residing in [[Bayonne]].
== The Jokari Company == The company does still exist, but has relocated to Carrollton, TX, and does not sell the game anymore. The Jokari company now manufactures and markets solution gadgets and storage and organization products, including the Fizz-Keeper, Purse Rack, and Can Caps.
== Cultural references == The game has reached some cult status in France, it is featured in several comics, and also in the [[James Bond]] [[Parody|spoof]] movie ''[[OSS 117: Cairo, Nest of Spies]]'' (2006), in the English translation of which the game is called "paddleball." Ian Fleming's character, James Bond, (in the first chapter of "On Her Majesty's Secret Service") also refers to the game Jokari as he is watching a bathing beach on the northern coast of France.
== External links == * [http://www.jokariinfo.net Detailed pictorial history of the Jokari paddleball game] * [http://www.jokari.com The Jokari corporate site] * [http://primghar.com/jokari/index.html Another Jokari game page]

page.title: List of Olympic Games scandals and controversies

revision.comment: /* {{anchor|1972 Summer Olympics}}1972 Summer Olympics – Munich, West Germany */
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}}{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=August 2016}} {{Olympic Games infobox}} The [[Olympic Games]] is a major international [[multi-sport event]]. During its history, both the [[Summer Olympic Games|Summer]] and [[Winter Olympic Games|Winter Games]] were a subject of many scandals, controversies, and illegal drug uses.
Some states have [[boycott]]ed the Games on various occasions, often as a sign of protest against the [[International Olympic Committee]], often having [[racial discrimination]] or contemporary politics of other participants. After both [[World Wars]], the losing countries were not invited. Other controversies include [[Doping_in_sport#By_country|doping programs]], decisions by [[referee]]s and even [[gesture]]s made by [[Sportsperson|athletes]].
==Summer Olympics==
==={{anchor|1908 Summer Olympics}}1908 Summer Olympics – London, United Kingdom===
* [[Grand Duchy of Finland]] competed separately from the [[Russian Empire]], but was not allowed to display the Finnish flag.<ref name=Politics-no-stranger>{{Cite news|last1= |first1= |date=9 May 1984|title= Politics no stranger to Olympic Games |newspaper=[[The Montreal Gazette]] |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=eVwxAAAAIBAJ&sjid=l6UFAAAAIBAJ&pg=6019,4341675 }}</ref> * In the [[Athletics at the 1908 Summer Olympics – Men's 400 metres|400 metres]], American winner [[John Carpenter (athlete)|John Carpenter]] was disqualified for blocking British athlete [[Wyndham Halswelle]] in a maneuver that was legal under U.S. rules but prohibited by the British rules under which the race was run. As a result of the disqualification, a second final race was ordered. Halswelle was to face the other two finalists [[William Robbins (athlete)|William Robbins]] and [[John Taylor (athlete)|John Taylor]], but both were from the United States and decided not to contest the repeat of the final to protest the judges' decision. Halswelle was thus the only medallist in the 400 metres. It was the only walkover victory in Olympic history. Taylor later ran on the Gold medal winning U.S. team for the now-defunct Medley Relay, becoming the first African American medallist.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historytalk.org/Notting%20Hill%20Sport/sport2web%20olympics.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-01-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120311011542/http://www.historytalk.org/Notting%20Hill%20Sport/sport2web%20olympics.pdf |archivedate=11 March 2012 |df= }} History Talk</ref>
==={{anchor|1912 Summer Olympics}}1912 Summer Olympics – Stockholm, Sweden=== * American athlete [[Jim Thorpe]] was stripped of his gold medals in the [[decathlon]] and [[pentathlon]] after it was learned that he had played professional minor league baseball three years earlier.<ref name="olympic.org">{{cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/uk/athletes/profiles/bio_uk.asp?PAR_I_ID=54230|title=International Olympic Committee – Athletes|accessdate=2008-08-16}}</ref> In solidarity, the decathlon silver medallist, [[Hugo Wieslander]], refused to accept the medals when they were offered to him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abebooks.com/docs/Community/Featured/olympics-crisis.shtml|title=AbeBooks: Crisis at the Olympics|accessdate=2008-08-16}}</ref> The gold medals were restored to Thorpe's children in 1983, thirty years after his death.<ref name="olympic.org"/>
==={{anchor|1916 Summer Olympics}}1916 Summer Olympics – [not held - World War I]=== * The [[1916 Summer Olympics]] were to have been held in Berlin, [[German Empire]], but were cancelled because of the outbreak of World War I.
==={{anchor|1920 Summer Olympics}}1920 Summer Olympics – Antwerp, Belgium=== * [[Budapest]] had initially been selected over [[Amsterdam]] and [[Lyon]] to host the Games, but as the [[Austro-Hungarian Empire]] had been a German ally in World War I, the French-dominated [[International Olympic Committee]] transferred the Games to [[Antwerp]] in April 1919. * Austria, Bulgaria, Germany, Hungary, and Turkey were not invited to the Games, being the [[succession of states|successor states]] of the [[Central Powers]] which lost World War I.<ref name=Politics-no-stranger />
==={{anchor|1924 Summer Olympics}}1924 Summer Olympics – Paris, France=== * Germany was again not invited to the Games.<ref name=GuttmannGermany>{{cite book |last=Guttmann |first=Allen |title=The Olympics: A History of the Modern Games |year= 1992 |publisher=University of Illinois Press |location=Urbana and Chicago |isbn=0-252-01701-3 |pages=38}}</ref>
==={{anchor|1932 Summer Olympics}}1932 Summer Olympics – Los Angeles, USA=== * Nine-time Finnish Olympic gold medallist [[Paavo Nurmi]] was found to be a professional athlete and barred from running in the Games. The main conductors of the ban were Swedish officials, especially [[Sigfrid Edström]], who claimed that Nurmi had received too much money for his travel expenses. However, Nurmi did travel to Los Angeles and kept training at the Olympic Village. Despite pleas from all the entrants of the marathon, he was not allowed to compete at the Games. This incident, in part, led to Finland refusing to participate in the traditional [[Finland-Sweden athletics international]] event until 1939. * After winning the silver in [[equestrian dressage]], Swedish equestrian [[Bertil Sandström]] was demoted to last for clicking to his horse to win encouragement. He asserted that it was a creaking saddle making the sounds.
==={{anchor|1936 Summer Olympics}}1936 Summer Olympics – Berlin, Germany=== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 146-1976-033-17, Berlin, Olympische Spiele.jpg|thumb|Adolf Hitler arriving at the opening ceremony of the controversial 1936 Berlin Games]] [[Image:Bundesarchiv Bild 183-G00630, Sommerolympiade, Siegerehrung Weitsprung.jpg|right|thumb| Jesse Owens on the podium after winning the long jump at the [[1936 Summer Olympics]]]] *In 1931 the IOC selected the German capital city Berlin as the host city of the [[1936 Summer Olympics]]. However, following [[Adolf Hitler's rise to power]] in 1933, the plans for the Olympic Games became entangled with the politics of the Nazi regime. [[Adolf Hitler]] regarded the event as 'his' Olympics and sought to exploit the Games for propaganda purposes, with the aim of showcasing the post-First World War Germany. In 1936, a number of prominent politicians and organizations called for a boycott of the Summer Olympics, while other campaigners called for the games to be relocated.<ref name="Newman">{{cite news |url=http://www.haaretz.com/hasen/spages/1009630.html|first=Saul|last=Newman|title=Why Grandpa boycotted the Olympics|work=Haaretz|accessdate=2008-08-09}}</ref><ref name=USHMM_boycott>{{cite web|title=The Movement to Boycott the Berlin Olympics of 1936|url=http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007087|work=Holocaust Encyclopedia|publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|accessdate=8 February 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202095138/http://www.ushmm.org/wlc/en/article.php?ModuleId=10007087|archivedate=2 February 2014 |date=June 2013}}</ref> *The [[Popular Front (Spain)|Popular Front]] government of Spain decided to boycott the Berlin Games entirely and, together with labour and socialist groups around the world, organized an alternative event, the [[People's Olympiad]]. The event did not take place however; just as the Games were about to begin the [[Spanish Civil War]] broke out and the People's Olympiad was cancelled. *In the United States, there was considerable debate about boycotting the Games.<ref>{{cite news |title=Gov. Earl Urges U.S. Olympic Ban. He Says Here Nazis Will 'Sell' Their Philosophy to All Who Attend the Games |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1935/12/04/archives/gov-earl-urges-us-olympic-ban-he-says-here-nazis-will-sell-their.html |quote=Governor George H. Earle of Pennsylvania and Mayor La Guardia joined last night with Alfred J. Lill, member of the American Olympic Committee; Eric Seelig, former amateur light-heavyweight boxing champion of Germany, and others, in urging American withdrawal from the Olympic Games in Berlin next year. |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |date=December 4, 1935 |accessdate=8 February 2014 }}</ref> A leading advocate of a boycott was U.S. athlete [[Ernest Lee Jahncke]], the son of a German immigrant, who was an IOC member. He was opposed by [[United States Olympic Committee]] president [[Avery Brundage]] and was eventually expelled from the IOC for encouraging athletes to boycott the Berlin Games. *International concern surrounded the ruling German [[Nazi Party|National Socialists']] ideology of [[Master race|racial superiority]] and its application at an international event such as the Olympics.<ref name=USHMM_boycott/><ref name=USHMM_nazification>{{cite web|title=Nazification of Sport|url=http://www.ushmm.org/exhibition/olympics/?content=sports&lang=en|work=The Nazi Olympics Berlin 1936 (Online Exhibition)|publisher=United States Holocaust Memorial Museum|accessdate=8 February 2014}}</ref> In 1934 Avery Brundage undertook a visit to Germany to investigate the treatment of Jews. When he returned, he reported, "I was given positive assurance in writing ... that there will be no discrimination against Jews.
